notes:
1. Definition

Electric charge is the fundamental physical property of matter that causes it to experience a force when placed in an electromagnetic field. There are two types of electric charge: positive and negative. Like charges repel each other, and opposite charges attract.

2. Unit of Charge

The SI unit of electric charge is the coulomb (C). It is a very large unit of charge.

3. Elementary Charge

The smallest unit of charge observed in nature is the elementary charge, denoted by $e$. The charge of a single proton is $+e$, and the charge of a single electron is $-e$. All free charges are integer multiples of this elementary charge.

$$e \approx 1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}$$

4. Conservation of Charge

The principle of conservation of charge states that the net electric charge in an isolated system remains constant. Charge is not created or destroyed; it is only transferred from one object to another.

solvedExamples.question: An object has an excess of $5.0 \times 10^{20}$ electrons. What is the net charge on the object?
solvedExamples.explanation:
The total charge $Q$ is the number of electrons ($n$) times the charge of a single electron ($-e$).
$Q = n \cdot (-e) = (5.0 \times 10^{20}) \cdot (-1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C})$
$Q \approx -80.1 \text{ C}$.

solvedExamples.question: How many electrons would be required to produce a net charge of -1.0 C?
solvedExamples.explanation:
The number of electrons ($n$) is the total charge ($Q$) divided by the charge of one electron ($-e$).
$n = \frac{Q}{-e} = \frac{-1.0 \text{ C}}{-1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C/electron}}$
$n \approx 6.24 \times 10^{18}$ electrons.
